ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

SINGAPORE'S ROLE IN UNITED NATIONS INTERNATIONAL
CHILDREN'S FUND PROGRAMME


    1. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance (i) what benefits does Singapore derive from the United Nations International Children's Fund programme: (ii) what part does Government play in carrying out the UNICEF programme in Singapore; and (iii) how does Singapore match UNICEF's contribution.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance (Mr Low Por Tuck) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply to the question:

    (i) The United Nations International Children's Fund programme has supplied Singapore with skimmed milk and other nourishment for distribution to children in welfare institutions, hospitals and schools. The value of milk supplied in 1960 will be about $96,000. In 1960, an order has been placed for the free supply of about $9,000 worth of medical equipment.

    (ii) The distribution of milk and other nourishment supplied by U.N.I.C.E.F. is undertaken by the Director of Social Welfare in conjunction with the Ministry of Health and voluntary welfare organisations.

    (iii) This Government contributes $20,000 annually to the fund.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, can I ask a supplementary question?

    Mr Speaker: The hon. Member should be a bit more rapid in rising. Yes, a supplementary question.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I wonder if the hon. Member can tell us whether the milk is being put to proper use?

    Mr Low Por Tuck: Yes.

    Mrs Seow Peck Leng: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I make myself clear? I asked that question because I happen to know that the milk supplied has such a very strong flavour that school children never like to take it. I happen to know this from my experience as a school principal. I know that the school children throw it into the drain. Much of the milk finds its way into the drain instead of benefiting the children. I wonder whether the hon. Member is aware that that is happening. I have a lot of trouble making the school children take it and I have to -

    Mr Speaker: Order. If the hon. Member stops at the question whether the Parliamentary Secretary knows the habits of school children in this matter, I think perhaps she will be in order. Mr Low Por Tuck.

    Mr Low Por Tuck: I am not aware of it.

ASSISTANCE FROM UNITED NATIONS
F.A.O., W.H.O. AND T.A.A.


    2. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Finance how much assistance does Singapore get from the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organisation, World Health Organisation and Technical Assistance Administration.

    Mr Low Por Tuck (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply to the question:

    (a) The assistance from the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organisation has been limited in the main to the supply of publications, bulletins and information on assistance on livestock, plant quarantine and on fisheries. In 1958, a Veterinary Officer attended an Agricultural Extension Seminar organised by the Organisation.

    (b) The World Health Organisation has for a number of years supplied specialist staff under its regular programme and Technical Assistance Programme. These staff have helped in nursing education, the preparation

Column: 828

of modern hospital records systems and the establishment of an island-wide domiciliary midwifery service. The estimated cost of the Organisation's expenditure on the aforementioned programme in 1960 amounts to U.S. $76,896.

    In addition, the Organisation has awarded a number of fellowships for advanced specialised training. In 1960, an award was given for a Public Health Tutor Course in the United Kingdom.

    (c) The United Nations Technical Assistance Administration in 1960 supplied an iron and steel expert on a 2½ months assignment to make initial investigations to consider the feasibility of establishing a steel industry in the State. Since October, there has been a seven-man Industrial Survey Team provided by the U.N.T.A.A. to assess the State's potential for industrial expansion.

    3. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Labour and Law when will the Women's Charter be reintroduced in this Assembly and the reason for the delay in reintroducing it.

PUBLICATION OF ASSEMBLY
DEBATES IN NEWSPAPERS
(Request for Statement)


    4. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Culture whether any guidance is exercised, either directly or indirectly, by the Government in regard to articles published in the newspapers with particular reference to reports of Assembly Debates, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

    Mr S. Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government answers enquiries from the Press to ascertain the correctness or otherwise of facts connected with Government matters. It also enlists the cooperation of the Press in giving publicity to important aspects of Government policy, for example, family planning.

ERECTION OF "HALT" SIGN AND NUMBER OF ACCIDENTS AT
CORNER OF STILL ROAD AND JOO CHIAT PLACE


    6. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for Home Affairs (i) when was the "Halt" sign at the corner of Still Road and Joo Chiat Place put up; and (ii) how many accidents occurred at this corner during the 10 months before and the 10 months after the sign was put up.

    During the ten months before the "Halt" sign was erected, there were three accidents - all of them classified as slight ones. During the ten months after the "Halt" sign was erected, there was only one slight accident.

PERMIT FOR PRINTING AND PUBLISHING OF NEWSPAPER
(Government policy)


    7. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Home Affairs what policy is adopted by the Government in the matter of granting a permit for the printing and publishing of a newspaper, and what are the conditions endorsed by him on such permits.

Sir, the policy at present followed under the Printing Presses Ordinance is to grant permits in all cases, save when it is considered that a publication will be used for the publication of material which is undesirable or which contravenes generally accepted standards of decency and morality or to promote alien loyalties among the people of Singapore or for subversive purposes. PERMITS FOR SALE AND DISTRIBUTION OF NEWSPAPERS
PUBLISHED OUTSIDE SINGAPORE
(Government policy)


    8. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Home Affairs what policy is adopted by the Government in the matter of granting permits for the sale and distribution of newspapers published outside Singapore.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, permits for the publication, sale or distribution in Singapore of newspapers printed or published in the Federation of Malaya are governed by the provisions of section 7A of the Printing Presses Ordinance, whilst the importation, sale or circulation of any publication printed or published abroad, other than in the Federation of Malaya, are controlled by the Undesirable Publications Ordinance.

    The issue of such permits under the Printing Presses Ordinance is guided by the same policy which I have enunciated in the answer to the previous question.

    The use of the Undesirable Publications Ordinance in respect of non-Federation of Malaya importation is also guided by the same policy, except that consideration of the bona fides and so forth of the printers and publishers, not being Malayan persons, is not necessary.

"MALAYAN EXPRESS" - APPLICATIONS FOR PERMIT FOR
SALE AND DISTRIBUTION IN SINGAPORE


    9. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether the first application for a permit for the sale and distribution in Singapore of the Malayan Express, published in Kuala Lumpur was refused, what were the grounds for the refusal, and whether the second application was allowed and on what grounds.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, the first application for the sale and distribution in Singapore of the Malayan Express was refused on the grounds that the applicant was the editor and publisher of the "Saturday Post" which was banned by the Federation.

    That the Saturday Post had published irresponsible articles and stories - not merely critical articles - was admitted by the applicant himself in a letter to the Minister for Culture. The applicant expressed regrets over the publication of such articles and assured that, as publisher and editor of the Malayan Express, he would see to it that he would not exceed the bounds of legitimate and responsible journalism.

    It was made clear to the applicant that the Government was not concerned with whether the paper was critical of or well disposed towards Government, but that it was concerned with the accuracy and responsibility with which articles and stories were presented.

    On this assurance by the applicant, the second application was approved. However, I understand that the Malayan Express has ceased publication of its own accord.

    This is not the first nor the last occasion when the Member for Joo Chiat has espoused lost causes.

APPLICATIONS FOR PERMITS TO PRINT AND PUBLISH
NEWSPAPERS SINCE 1ST JANUARY, 1960


    10. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Home Affairs how many applications for permits to print and publish newspapers were received since 1st January, 1960, how many were granted, how many were refused, and what are the reasons for refusal in each case.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, since 1st January to October 1960, 204 applications for permits were received. Of these, 134 were approved and permits issued, 56 are still under consideration, six have been withdrawn by the applicants, and seven had been refused. The reasons for refusal are as follows:

    (a) three cases in which the publishers, or editors, or both, were found not to be proper persons to be granted permits.

    (b) three cases in which the publishers, or editors, or both, were found incompetent to produce newspapers.

    (c) one case in which the newspaper is the publication of a society which has been dissolved under section 17 of the Societies Ordinance.

    11. Mr C. H. Koh asked the Minister for Home Affairs what was the nature of the undertaking given by the Chinese reporter of the Tiger Press of Kuala Lumpur for his release from detention under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955.

HOUSING BOARD ESTATES
(Sweeping and collection of rubbish)


    13. Mrs Seow Peck Leng asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that on Sundays and public holidays some Housing Board Estates are not swept and the rubbish there is not collected, and what steps does he propose to take in the matter.

    Mr Tan Kia Gan: Mr Speaker, I have been informed by the Housing and Development Board that, in accordance with an agreement made with the Labour Union, the Board's labourers are not called out for sweeping and collection of rubbish in the housing estates on Sundays. The hon. Member is no doubt aware that section 41 of the Labour Ordinance, 1955, provides that:

    "...in any week there shall be a rest day, which shall be Sunday or any other day as may be agreed by the employer and workman.'

Labourers are called out for work on any public holiday falling on a Saturday or Monday, in order to avoid accumulation of rubbish in the Estates for more than one day.

    I have been assured by the Board that no health hazards are likely to arise from this practice, as the housing estates are well spaced out and the rubbish bins provided have been specially made to keep two days' refuse. CRIMINAL LAW (TEMPORARY PROVISIONS)

(AMENDMENT NO. 2) BILL

First Reading


3.08 p.m.

    The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to introduce a Bill intituled "An Ordinance to amend the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1955."

    Bill read the First time.

Column: 839

Second Reading


    Mr Speaker: Second Reading, what day?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Now, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: Please proceed.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I lay upon the Table a Certificate of Urgency signed by the Yang di-Pertuan Negara in respect of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) (Amendment No. 2) Bill.

    Certificate of Urgency handed in.

    Mr Speaker: The Certificate is in order. Are typed copies of the Bill available for the use of Members?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Yes.

    Typed copies of the Bill handed in to the Clerk and distributed to hon. Members.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Sir, this short Bill seeks to amend section 49A of the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1955, by empowering the Minister to direct that a person, placed under the supervision of the Police under the provisions of the Ordinance, shall not be permitted to enter any area specified in the Order.

    When the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Amendment Bill was moved in August 1959, it was intended that power should be granted to the Minister to direct that a supervisee shall remain within doors and to prohibit the supervisee from visiting specified areas which have been the scene of his past criminal activities. When the law was passed, the power of the Minister to direct that a supervisee shall remain within such area as may be specified in a Supervision Order was interpreted to mean that a person under Supervision Order can be prohibited from visiting any area specified in the Order. In an appeal against the acquittal of a supervisee for breaking this condition, it was held by the High Court that the power to confine a person on a Supervision Order to a particular area does not entitle the Minister to impose the condition that

Column: 840

he shall not visit the area specified in the Order.

    Sir, in Government's campaign against secret societies, it has been found that such a provision in the Criminal Law has been effective in curbing secret society activities. The continued use of this condition is therefore very desirable in order to prevent persons placed under Supervision Orders from visiting areas which have been the scene of their past secret society activities. The Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance is therefore being amended to make this condition intra vires the law. This condition is used judiciously and is applied mainly to those secret society gangsters who, although they do not live or work in certain streets or areas, have been concentrating their activities or exerting their evil influence in those streets or areas. These streets or areas have been well rid of the presence of these social parasites. This amendment to the law, Sir, follows a similar provision in the Prevention of Crime Ordinance, 1959, of the Federation of Malaya.

    Sir, with the help of the powers granted under the Criminal Law (Temporary Provisions) Ordinance, 1955, the Government has dealt telling blows on secret society activities and is getting on top of the situation. The secret society menace is now being dealt with under a two-pronged strategy. On the one hand, thugs and gangsters are being continually kept on the run, while on the other hand those under detention are now being channelled through the educative and rehabilitative process of the Pulau Senang scheme. The Pulau Senang experiment has gone off to a good start and its present progress gives cause for hope in the future.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itsself into a Committee on the Bill.-[Mr Ong Pang Boon].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

QUEEN STREET AND SILAT ROAD SIKH GURDAWARAS BILL


Introduction and First Reading


    Mr John Mammen (Telok Blangah): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,
